title: Cy Buker
text:
Cyril Owen Buker (February 5, 1918 – October 11, 2011) was a <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who played for the <a href="Brooklyn%20Dodgers">Brooklyn Dodgers</a> in 1945. The 26-year-old <a href="rookie">rookie</a> right-hander stood and weighed .
Buker is one of many ballplayers who only appeared in the <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">major league</a>s during World War II. He made his <a href="major%20league%20debut">major league debut</a> in relief on May 17, 1945, against the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> at <a href="Ebbets%20Field">Ebbets Field</a>. His first major league <a href="Win%20%28baseball%29">win</a> came in his first start, on June 21, 1945, as the Dodgers defeated the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> 9–2 at <a href="Shibe%20Park">Shibe Park</a>. <a href="Andy%20Karl%20%28baseball%29">Andy Karl</a> was the losing pitcher.
His season and career totals for 42 games include a 7–2 record, four <a href="games%20started">games started</a>, 22 <a href="games%20finished">games finished</a>, five <a href="save%20%28sport%29">saves</a>, and an <a href="earned%20run%20average">ERA</a> of 3.30 in 87 <a href="innings%20pitched">innings pitched</a>. Besides pitching well, Buker could swing the bat. He was 3-for-16 (.188) with a <a href="bases%20on%20balls">walk</a> and two <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a>.
Following his Brooklyn days, Buker eventually returned to his hometown of <a href="Greenwood%2C%20Wisconsin">Greenwood, Wisconsin</a> where he began a successful coaching career, eventually being named to the Wisconsin Football and Basketball Coaches Association Hall of Fame. His son, Tom, would later coach at the school, leading it to class C titles in boys' basketball and baseball in 1988.
Buker died on October 11, 2011, in Greenwood, Wisconsin.
